ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I had never taken Latin before and this class was an amazing intro to the language. I feel that I have gained insight not only into an ancient language and culture, but also into the evolution of modern language.
I learned to read Latin! I'm very appreciative of that result.
I learned a lot about latin grammar and how to analyze a latin sentence.
Basics of Latin grammar and how to approach an ancient language in a methodical manner.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Although it was a bit annoying to meet everyday, we were able to very effectively cover the material. The textbook and workbook were both useful. Weekly quizzes were helpful for keeping us on top of studying. Weaknesses: There was was seemed to be an excessive amount of homework. I understand (and admittedly somewhat agree with) its usefulness, but at the end of the semester it was difficult to manage. All in all, though, that's a fairly minor complaint and something I wouldn't actually expect to be changed.

This course is very fast paced and allots the same amount of time per concept not matter the difficulty. This makes it very difficult when whizzing through so much. In class, mostly the concepts are taught and then you're left by yourself to summarize them and apply the. This course could be improved by changing the amounts of time the instructors choose to go over things, like subjunctives and clauses. At the beginning of the course there were daily quizzes and daily in-depth homework checks that were tough but encouraged growth in learning; however these stopped and we stopped getting constant feed back. Since you cannot speak in Latin, it is a lot harder to cement concepts, so there is a lot of homework.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to anyone who wants a language that is challenging but interesting.

Certainly, though from conversations with other students, the instructor you get can make a big difference. So, I suppose, I would recommend the course if Joe (or someone who could do an equally good job) were teaching.
No, Latin is interesting but doesn't have many applications and this course is a lot of work. I would recommend a spoken language.
Only if they have a specific interest in classics or Roman history. The course is enough work to make someone reconsider taking it on a whim.
